The Date and the Meaning of the Vettius Affair
49
and praetors.  That was clear when the elections for 58 finally came,  for,  though Caesar's consular candidates won,  two of his bitter enemies,  Domitius and Memmius,  were elected to the praetorship.  The voters who counted in the centuriate assembly were the propertied men from the Italian towns who regularly came in large numbers to Rome to take part in campaigns and elections Many of these Italians were adherents of Caesar's opponents,  the honi or optimales in the nobility,  and were ready to vote for the candidates whom their patrons commended. 
Now in July of 59 the good men were busy trying to discredit the men in power,  and to electioneer for their candidates.  The consul Bibulus was posting edicts with scurrilous charges against Caesar and Pompey.  In electioneering the younger Curio was very active and,  as we know from Cicero he was influential with the voting groups.  Organized tions,  for which Curio must have been reponsible,  had already occurred at a gladiatorial show and in the theater.  Curio himself had been applauded,  Caesar had been received in silence,  and one of his henchmen had been hissed.  Particularly significant was the action of the knigths who rose in the theater to greet Curio,  Such a demonstration was,  I think,  made possible by the arrival for the elections of many knights from the Italian towns
In order to bring Curio into suspicion — here I follow Cicero's estimate of the situation — Caesar had approadied Vettius and induced him to try to involve Curio in a plot to kill Pompey.  But the plan did not work,  for Curio told his father.  The elder Curio told Pompey,  who reported the matter to the senate.  Vettius was called in and,  after initial denial,  gave a list of young blades who were alleged to have been ciated in the plot under Curio's leadership.  Besides Lentulus,  son of the consular candidate,  who,  Vettius charged,  also knew about the plot,  the list comprised M.  lunius Brutus and L.  Aemilius Paulus.  Vettius stated that he had received a dagger from a scribe of the consul Bibulus.  According to Cicero,  it amused the senator«^ that Vettius should have had no other means of getting a dagger ; besides,  Cicero adds,  Pompey had
11.  For the evidence see my Party Politics in the Age of Caesar ( Berkeley,  1949 ) Chap.  III. 
12.  See the letter urging Curio to support Milo for the consulship,  ad F am.  II 6 ; on Curious influence on Antony's election to the augurate see Phil.  II 4.  On the fluence of adulescentes nobile s on the elections see Q.  Cicero,  Comm.  Pet.  6 and 33. 
13.  On the demonstrations see ad Att.  II 18—19.  Cf.  note 8 above.  Scholars have been puzzled by the attitude of the knights,  one group of whom,  the publicans,  had lately been favored by Caesar's law revising the contracts in Asia.  But the knights were not a united group.  Caesar was said to have threatened the knights not with a cancellation of the new contracts,  but with the loss of their special seats in the theater.  I assume that at the theater on this occasion the seats were occupied chiefly by men of equestrian rank frcm the Italian towns.
